data.title: Workspace can't be saved with same name error
data.body:
Version: 1.15.0-insider
Commit SHA: 56a5bf1
Date: 2017-07-13T06:24:22.570Z
Shell 1.6.6
Renderer 56.0.2924.87
Node 7.4.0
Architecture x64
Ubuntu 16.04

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a workspace as "asdf" and save it.
2. Create another workspace "asdf" and save it.  
3. The file window prompts the warning about overriding a file like normal, and I select to override this file, but then I'm presented with an error inside of the editor after the file save process:
Error: A workspace with the same name already exists at the provided location.

I would expect that my workspace name would be overwritten, and the contents of asdf.code would be updated with the new workspace asdf.code data since I already instructed that I wanted this to happen to the system.  Another approach might be prompting the user to pick a directory for their workspace and enter a name, but only allow dir selection, not file and require the name to be entered

Does this with and without extension enabled.

data.title: Feature Request: Update application window with Workspace name prepended
data.body:
Version: 1.15.0-insider
Commit SHA: 56a5bf1724f3b882e149a3e7a24e6105a7b837c2
Date: 2017-07-13T06:24:22.570Z
Shell 1.6.6
Renderer 56.0.2924.87
Node 7.4.0
Architecture x64
Ubuntu 16.04

When I select a file the application's toolbar is updated with the filename followed by an emdash Visual Studio (in this case - Insider ).  This is great so I can reference the window easily when I have multiple windows open.  When I'm in a Workspace and have multiple Workspaces open in different windows, it's hard to tell which window is what at a glance since I usually am looking at that area.

data.title: Workspace name is always UNTITLED WORKSPACE
data.body:
Version: 1.15.0-insider
Commit SHA: 56a5bf1
Date: 2017-07-13T06:24:22.570Z
Shell 1.6.6
Renderer 56.0.2924.87
Node 7.4.0
Architecture x64
Ubuntu 16.04

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a new workspace by going to "File > Workspaces > New Workspace..."  This adds the "UNTITLED WORKSPACE" to the sidebar.
2. I added a new file to the workspace called asdf.txt with contents asdf by pressing the icon to add file next to workspace name.
3.  Next I went to "File > Workspaces > Save Workspace..."  I saved the workspace as ~/asdfworkspace.code
4. Close the editor, and then reopen it.

The result is that the workspace still has the name UNTITLED WORKSPACE.  I expected this to have the name given to the workspace when saved.

Does this with and without extension enabled.

data.title: Adding multiple folders to Workspace only remembers last folder added in new session after closing.
data.body:
Version: 1.15.0-insider
Commit SHA: 56a5bf1
Date: 2017-07-13T06:24:22.570Z
Shell 1.6.6
Renderer 56.0.2924.87
Node 7.4.0
Architecture x64
Ubuntu 16.04

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a new Workspace by going to "File > Workspaces > New Workspace..."  This adds the "UNTITLED WORKSPACE" to the sidebar.
2. Add an existing folder to Workspace - I right clicked then clicked "Add Folder to Workspace."  The folder was a .git repo, and it did not appear in the side bar mentioned in Issue #30782
3. Add another existing folder to Workspace -  I right clicked then clicked "Add Folder to Workspace."  The folder was a .git repo, and it did not appear in the side bar also.
4. Close the editor, and then reopen it.

The result is that only the last folder added to Workspace is added in the sidebar.  I expected to see both folders that were added .

Does this with and without extension enabled.

data.title: Failed at the electron-mksnapshot@1.6.0 install script
data.body:
Downloaded vscode source . Following their instructions to build , when I ran
 
    scripts\npm.bat install

 Failed at the electron-mksnapshot@1.6.0 install script.

the console also shows the below:

     D:\vscode-master\node_modules\extract-zip\index.js:35
      zipfile.readEntry()
              ^

    TypeError: zipfile.readEntry is not a function
    at D:\vscode-master\node_modules\extract-zip\index.js:35:15
    at D:\vscode-master\node_modules\yauzl\index.js:31:7
    at D:\vscode-master\node_modules\yauzl\index.js:96:14
    at D:\vscode-master\node_modules\yauzl\index.js:342:5
    at D:\vscode-master\node_modules\fd-slicer\index.js:32:7
    at FSReqWrap.wrapper [as oncomplete] (fs.js:629:17)


I have installed extract-zip v 1.6.5 , this is mentioned in dependency. No Idea what is going wrong here. I deleted the node_modules and build file and checked again. Does not seem to work.  I have asked a [question](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/45121679/failed-at-the-electron-mksnapshot1-6-0-install-script) at stackoverflow too.

data.title: Clicking on JavaScript comment lines in HTML causes error
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.1 (2648980a697a4c8fb5777dcfb2ab110cec8a2f58, 2017-07-13T19:18:47.188Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
- Extensions: none
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a file with the `HTML` language mode with the following contents:

```html
<html>
  <head>
    <script>
      // Comment.
    </script>
  </head>
  <body>
  </body>
</html>

```
2. Click on the line with the comment in the `<script>` tag.

3. The `Output` window will open with a message like the following:

```
[Error - 2:44:26 PM] Request textDocument/documentHighlight failed.
  Message: Request textDocument/documentHighlight failed with message: Cannot read property 'kind' of undefined
  Code: -32603 
```

data.title: Menu keybinding labels are not translated according to locale

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.1 (2648980a697a4c8fb5777dcfb2ab110cec8a2f58, 2017-07-13T19:18:47.188Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
csharp|ms-|1.11.0

---

The menu "Los" is not understandable. Is it a fate, or a lot, or a batch, or does it mean "Let's go!" Go … where? Was that "Go" in English? That would be "gehen" in German. Probably just a stupid as in English. It might be helpful to use the translation for "Go to" which would be "Gehe zu". Some commands in that menu are actually called "Gehe zu (…)".

The second command in that menu is "Weiterleiten" which means forwarding something to somebody. An e-mail message for example, that can be forwarded. From the surrounding commands I guess that you did not mean "to forward" but "the direction forward" which is "vorwärts" in German. The opposite of "zurück" ("back").

Also, the hotkeys are highly inconsistent. Some are positioned at the right end of the menu popup, in grey colour, but completely in English. Others are appended to the command text, left-aligned, in black colour, and partially translated ("Ctrl" was translated to "STRG" (correct would be "Strg") and arrow key names are still in English). These have brackets around them. Why does it look like somebody threw a bomb in there?

data.title: allow disable of recent history in "go to file" command
data.body:
I'd like the ability to disable showing the "recent history" portion of the file list in the `go to file` command, or at least collapsed so I don't have to visually scan to find the files list. 

For me, it quickly becomes both noisey (lots of false matches that I have to visually skip) and incorrect (debugger files, old files, etc).  

I find myself clearing the history multiple times daily to limit the noise.  The pattern matching as currently implemented is great, quickly gets me a short list of matching files, and the "recent" list just adds noise.

data.title: Snippet placeholder index incorrect after using 2+ snippets in a row that each end with a placeholder
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.14.1
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.5

![snip](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24303763/28240960-a4e1252c-693f-11e7-972f-d7e836404c70.gif)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Add this snippet to any language (I used Batch but the language doesn't seem to matter)
```json
"Test": {
	"prefix": "test",
	"body": [ "test ${1:replaceme}" ]
}
```
2. Open a fresh file in the snippet's language
3. Type "te" and hit return to activate the snippet
4. Type a value to replace the placeholder
5. Hit return to go to the next line
6. Repeat steps 2-5
7. Repeat step 3
8. Observe that your curser is now AFTER the placeholder and the placeholder isn't selected
9. Optionally continue repeating and observe that previous placeholders become highlighted unexpectedly

I expected that the snippets would continue to behave as they did for the first two lines. This issue also occurs when using a `CompletionItemProvider` in an extension to provide completions with `SnippetString`s. Note that if that there are any characters after the placeholder in the snippet, e.g. `"body": [ "test ${1:replaceme}_" ]`, the issue does not occur. 

EDIT: I tested this issue against version 1.15.0-insider, and the behavior is different, but it is still reproducible in the same way (fewer steps, actually). Let me know if a separate issue for that version would be helpful!

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Installation instructions for Fedora are outdated
data.body:
Check header **RHEL, Fedora and CentOS based distributions** [here](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/setup/linux):

```
sudo rpm --import https://packages.microsoft.com/keys/microsoft.asc
sudo sh -c 'echo -e "[code]\nname=Visual Studio Code\nbaseurl=https://packages.microsoft.com/yumrepos/vscode\nenabled=1\ngpgcheck=1\ngpgkey=https://packages.microsoft.com/keys/microsoft.asc" > /etc/yum.repos.d/vscode.repo'
```

Running the code above results in the following error on Fedora 26:
`sh: /etc/zypp/repos.d/vscode.repo: No such file or directory`

The fix on how to get it to work is on [this page](https://blog.lenzg.net/2017/02/installing-microsoft-visual-studio-code-on-fedora-linux/):

Create file `/etc/yum.repos.d/vscode.repo` with the following content:

```
[code]
name=Visual Studio Code
baseurl=https://packages.microsoft.com/yumrepos/vscode
enabled=1
gpgcheck=1
gpgkey=https://packages.microsoft.com/keys/microsoft.asc
``` 
For new users, it might be a good idea to update the website reflecting this.

data.title: Build task does not stop launch with Tasks 2.0.0
data.body:
VSCode 1.14.1
C# 1.11.0

When moving from Tasks 0.1.0 to Tasks 2.0.0 an unsuccessful build no longer displays the following message:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7782966/28240356-c4f9d624-6980-11e7-8cc6-38fafd4c52b8.png)

Instead, the previously generated code is executed and the debugger attached.

Steps to reproduce:
Create a new C# console application:

    dotnet new console

Allow VSCode to add tasks.json and launch.json.
Create an error in the code (like CConsole.WriteLine) and launch it. This displays the error and does NOT launch a debug session.

Then open tasks.json and modify to

    "version": "2.0.0"

Build and launch again. This time, the terminal displays the error but still attempts to execute the previous build output.

A minimal solution is attached to this post:
[TasksRepro.zip](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/1150422/TasksRepro.zip)

data.title: node-debug: liveness tracking of debuggee doesn't work for WSL
data.body:
The node-debugger uses the PID for tracking the liveness of debuggee if the debuggee was started indirectly in a terminal (and the debug adapter is not automatically informed about the termination of the debuggee).

On Windows WSL this approach doesn't work because WSL apps have separate PIDs from the rest of the system. node-debug will test if the Node.js is alive every couple of seconds, but since it uses PIDs from the WSL it will not find Node.js running and will terminate the session.

- VSCode Version: 1.14.1

2. open integrated terminal

5. save file dialog appears with filename `download.html`

data.title: Closing absent file panes on change of git branch should restore when branch is switched back

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I have a fairly common annoyance when switching between branches.

If a set of files I am working on is not present in a branch I switch to for a moment, to make a hotfix or somesuch, then VS Code closes all the panes that are not present in the new branch -- this is sensible.  However, when I switch back to the branch I was previously working on, they should be reopened.  As I have not requested the files to be closed, so should be open whilst they are present.

------

- VSCode Version: 1.13.1
- OS Version: Windows 7

Steps to Reproduce:

1.  Open files present in a git branch
2.  Checkout a different branch where those files are not present
3.  Checkout the original branch

data.title: Make npm install work again with NPM 5
data.body:
Two issues fixed:

1. I think there was a version string mismatch which was causing the mainstream `v8-profiler` to be installed instead of the vscode electron-compatible fork in the shrinkwrap. This was causing the node-gyp step for v8-profiler package to fail with a build error

2. Once the above was fixed then the extract of some electron bits started failing. Updating the `yauzl` package used for unzipping stuff fixed that. I suspect something was happening under the hood that resulted in a version mismatch between `extract-zip` and `yauzl`. The future proof fix here will be to update to NPM5 package lock files I guess.
 
Relates to #30134

data.title: Can not update language specific configuration
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.14.1 
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.5

I have developed a markdown extension. To improve experience, I want to set the `markdown quickSuggetions: true` as default when activating my extension. Here is my code, but the configuration did not update correctly. Other settings, such as `files.eol` works fine. Did I miss anything? Or the API does not support modify?

``` js
const markdownSettings = vscode.workspace.getConfiguration("[markdown]");
markdownSettings.update("editor.quickSuggestions", true, true);
```

data.title: Ubuntu Unity: VSCode doesn't restore windows after Quit from Launcher

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.1 (2648980a697a4c8fb5777dcfb2ab110cec8a2f58, 2017-07-13T19:12:01.887Z)
- OS Version: Ubuntu 17.04 Unity, Linux x64 4.10.0-26-generic
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
codeception-snippets|die|0.0.4
githistory|don|0.2.1
php-debug|fel|1.11.1
php-intellisense|fel|1.4.3
AWK|lug|0.0.2
ftp-sync|luk|0.3.3
code-beautifier|mic|1.7.2
mads|mir|0.0.5
HTMLHint|mka|0.3.3
vscode-icons|rob|7.10.1
code-spell-checker|str|1.2.1



---

**Steps to Reproduce:**

1. Open VSCode using shortcut in Unity Launcher
2. Set `"window.restoreWindows": "folders"` or `"window.restoreWindows": "all"` in your user settings
3. Open folder A
4. Open folder B
5. Close VSCode using the action Quit in Launcher:
![fayngjtens](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12584138/28238088-98fc37da-694c-11e7-9bd6-09740329e2ea.png)
6. Open VScode again using shortcut in Unity Launcher

**Expected result:**
- the windows with the folders A and B are restored

**Actual result**
- no window is restored, you get only an empty window

**Note:** If you close VSCode using the shortcut `Ctrl + Q`, the windows are restored well.
